Job Summary:
CO-OP positions in the Economic Analysis Directorate 

Environment and Climate Change Canada (ECCC) 


Job Title: Economist/Analyst 

The Economic Analysis Directorate is seeking to fill a number of co-op positions in its four divisions (see the last page of this document for more details). We offer a fast-paced work environment where key environmental policies are put to the test using economic and policy analysis, and innovative valuation techniques. We are also challenged by some of the most significant policy questions facing government and Canadian society today including those related to climate change, air pollution, and water quality. 


For more information on Environment and Climate Change Canada, see our internet site: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change.html 


About the job: 

- Monday through Friday, 8:30 - 4:30 (hours are flexible). Students must be available to work 37.5 hours per week. Co-op work term starts on January 3 and ends on April 29, 2022 (dates are flexible). Terms can be extended to 8 months under certain circumstances. 


Due to COVID 19, most federal employees are working remotely, where possible. COOP students 

in the Winter 2022 term are expected to work remotely, using their phones and computer provided by Environment and Climate Change Canada. The department will send the computer before the start of the co?op term.  

- To be eligible, you must be officially registered in a co-operative education or internship program 

with a University and be registered in a graduate program.
Job Responsibilities:
Key Activities: 

Depending on the position, your duties may include: 

- Economic and policy research on domestic and international policy issues such as climate change, air pollution, sustainable development, clean growth, and environmental regulations. 

- Development of tools and techniques for energy, emissions and economic forecasting, and for valuing environmental resources for use in cost-benefit analyses and other program and policy applications. 

- Summaries and analyses of third-party research findings for use by Senior Management. 

- Support key departmental initiatives, such as an expert speaker series and research network. 


Description of work undertaken by divisions within the Economic Analysis Directorate:

  

Current Analysis and Economic Research Division


The Current Analysis and Economic Research Division undertakes major research projects with important environmental policy relevance, such as Canada's Mid-Century Strategy. It develops metrics such as the Social Cost of Carbon, and develops assessments of the upstream greenhouse gas emissions associated with major energy and infrastructure projects. The division leads the department's work on files like fossil fuel subsidy reform and sustainable finance, including climate-related financial risk disclosure. The division also analyzes the competitiveness impacts of proposed environmental policies, such as regulations and carbon pricing.  


  

Model Development and Quantitative Research Division


The Model Development and Quantitative Research Division's mandate is to provide model?based analytical support to key policies such as carbon pricing and its competitiveness impacts, (e.g., see Economic analysis of the Pan-Canadian Framework - Canada.ca), comparability of greenhouse gas mitigation efforts across countries and long-term technology?based issues such as the implications of 1.5 and 2°C emission pathways and transition to a low carbon economy. The division also develops provincial and territorial macroeconomic projections that support the development of Canada's GHG and air pollutant projections. In undertaking its mandate, the division maintains and uses a suite of Canadian provincial and international Computable General Equilibrium and Integrated Assessment Models for policy design and analysis to support domestic and international policy agenda. The division also maintains a detailed macroeconomic model - The Informetrica Model. With evolving policy priorities and needs, this division's activities provide opportunities for innovation in economic modeling. The division plays an active role in policy development through collaborative research such as Stanford's Energy Modeling Forum, academic engagement and publications in scientific journals such as Energy Economics, Energy Journal, and Climate Change Economics. 


Analysis and Modelling Division


The Analysis and Modeling Division's key mandate is the annual publication of Canada's GHG and air pollutant emissions projections. The division also supports reporting obligations domestically and internationally to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) such as Canada's Seventh National Communication on Climate Change and Fourth Biennial Report, as well as to the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution (CLRTAP) under the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE). In addition, the division supports policy and regulatory development using its Energy, Emissions and Economy Model for Canada (E3MC). 


Regulatory Analysis and Valuation Division


The Regulatory Analysis and Valuation Division conducts economic, cost-benefit, and regulatory analysis for a wide range of regulatory proposals under three Acts; the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, the Species at Risk Act, and the Fisheries Act, covering transportation, fuels, electricity, oil and gas, chemicals, mining, pulp and paper and other industrial sectors summarized and published in the Canada Gazette within the Regulatory Impact Analysis Statement. 

  

As well, the division is the department's center of expertise for cost-benefit analysis applied to regulatory proposals, such as for the Regulations Amending the Reduction of Carbon Dioxide Emissions from Coal-fired Generation of Electricity Regulations (http://gazette.gc.ca/rp-pr/p2/2018/2018-12-12/html/sor-dors263-eng.html). The division responds to increasing expectations for economic analysis in areas such as climate change, air pollution, chemicals management, species at risk, protected areas, environmental impact assessment, and enforcement. Its work informs decisions on stringency and regulatory design for the Government of Canada's environmental regulatory agenda. The division also develops and maintains the capacity for economic valuation of environmental benefits, including air and water quality modelling and the Environmental Valuation Reference Inventory (http://www.evri.ca/).
Required Skills:
Key Competencies: 

- You must have studied or are studying at the graduate (Masters) level with a specialization in economics, public administration, international affairs, political science or environmental studies. Focus on environmental economics is an asset. 

- You have an understanding of economic theory, cost-benefit analysis and have strong analytical skills. 

- You demonstrate an interest in environmental or natural resource economics, or environmental policy. 

- You are comfortable with inter-disciplinary and interpersonal communication. 

- You have good writing skills; you have prepared and have the capacity to present high-quality documents and presentations, often on short notice. 

- You display initiative and sound judgment. 

- You are self-motivated and dependable. 


Preference will be given to Canadian citizens. 

The Public Service of Canada promotes Employment Equity and we encourage candidates to 

voluntarily self-identify if they are women, members of a visible minority, person with a disability 

and/or Aboriginal person.

Job Summary:
At Environment and Climate Change Canada (ECCC), our business is protecting the environment, conserving the country's natural heritage, and providing weather and meteorological information to keep Canadians informed and safe. 


ECCC is building on its accomplishments with the environment through credible science, effective regulations and legislation, successful partnerships, and high-quality service delivery to Canadians. 


We support sound environmental decisions. We work to repair the damage of the past, to collect and pass on knowledge, and to develop, implement and enforce policies to prevent future issues. We also work to ensure that Canadians have a safe, clean and sustainable environment today, tomorrow and well into the future. 


ECCC is a diverse organization where our programs, services, and people lead the way in implementing the Government of Canada's environmental agenda. We collaborate with our partners at home and abroad, to realize concrete progress on initiatives that will protect the health of our people and our planet. 


Environment Canada's mandate is to:

preserve and enhance the quality of the natural environment, including water, air, soil, flora and fauna;
conserve Canada's renewable resources;
conserve and protect Canada's water resources;
forecast daily weather conditions and warnings, and provide detailed meteorological information to all of Canada;
enforce rules relating to boundary waters; and
coordinate environmental policies and programs for the federal government.

Our workforce is made up of knowledgeable and dedicated employees from diverse backgrounds that are proud of the contribution they make to the environment. We have 6800 employees from a broad range of fields including biology, chemistry, meteorology, climatology, engineering, commerce, communications, engineering, law enforcement, environmental sciences, hydrology, informatics, law, library science, policy, and more. 


Our employees work in over 100 communities across the country, from Iqaluit to Toronto and Vancouver to St. John's. Over 65 per cent of our workforce is located outside of Ottawa. 

Our diverse expertise strengthens our ability to deal with increasingly complex and changing environmental issues. From the Canadian Ice Service to the Canadian Hurricane Centre, from laboratories and weather stations to national wildlife areas and field offices-our people deliver quality services. 


For more information about Environment and Climate Change Canada please visit our web site at http://www.ec.gc.ca.
Job Responsibilities:
The Organics Analysis Laboratory (OAL) of Environment Canada provides analytical services for the following Science and Technology Branch activities:

Air monitoring of organic contaminants in the Arctic under the Northern Contaminants Program (NCP) and the Chemicals Management Plan (CMP).
Air monitoring and surveillance of organic contaminants in the Great Lakes Basin (GLB) in support of the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement (GLWQA) and CMP.
Air monitoring and surveillance in the Oil Sands Region in support of the Joint Canada-Alberta Implementation Plan for Oil Sands Monitoring (JOSM)
Air monitoring and surveillance of organic pollutants in the St. Lawrence River Salish Sea in support of the Whale Recovery Initiative.  
These contaminants include polycyclic aromatic compounds, polybrominated diphenylethers polychlorinated biphenyls organochlorine pesticides, perfluorinated compounds.

Job Duties

 The successful applicant will provide support in the Organics Analysis Laboratory:
 Carry out sample preparation (extraction and cleanup) of samples collected from the NCP and GLB networks.
 Laboratory glassware washing.
 Assist with the disposable of the organic solvent waste.
Required Skills:
The applicant should have successfully completed at minimum, the first year of University in Chemistry, Environmental Chemistry, Environmental Science or similar. 
	 
  
Specific courses required are analytical chemistry and organic chemistry and/or environmental/atmospheric chemistry.
Laboratory experience is a minimum (e.g., working with solvents and knowledge of safe laboratory practices).
Detail-oriented.
Ability to work well in a team environment.
Dependable and self motivated.
Ability to communicate effectively.
Previous laboratory experience in analytical and wet chemistry and familiarity with gas chromatography or liquid chromatography are assets.


Preference will be given to Canadian citizens.  Proof of citizenship must be provided at the time of the interview.  Applicants will be subject to a security clearance check prior to being offered a letter of employment (form to be completed prior to the interview). This is an English essential position.  Applicants should have a functional understanding and practical grasp of the English language and be able to communicate effectively in that language.

Job Summary:
Scientific Data Analyst 

We have a one-term position available within the Climate Research Division of Environment and Climate Change Canada, located at 4905 Dufferin Street, Toronto, Ontario. 

  

Summary of Duties 

We are looking for a student with an interest in environment and climate change research to help prepare data for use in the evaluation and development of the Canadian Land Surface Scheme including Biogeochemical Cycles (CLASSIC). CLASSIC is the land surface component of the Canadian Earth System Model (CanESM), which is the climate model developed at Environment and Climate Change Canada for producing climate change scenarios and participates in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP) of the World Climate Research Programme. Experience will be gained with the HDF and NetCDF file formats commonly used for satellite-derived remote sensing and climate model data. 

  

Note:   A Reliability Status Security Clearance is required as a condition of employment. A Personnel Security Screening Form (to be provided by employer) must be completed. 

Citizenship:  In keeping with section 39(1) (c) of the Public Service Employment Act, preference must be given to Canadian citizens. Accordingly, a work term must be offered to a Canadian who meets the student requirements before the position can be offered to a non-Canadian student.
Job Responsibilities:
The duties of the position may include the following tasks: 

1. Gathering and categorizing of land surface and/or meteorological datasets from observations, remote sensing and numerical models. 

2. Processing of scientific data with data analysis and visualization software (e.g., Python, shell scripting, IDL, Microsoft Excel, as well as other software developed in house).
Required Skills:
Qualifications: 

The position requires experience with computer programming, such as shell scripting, IDL, or Python. Previous experience working with other programming languages and scientific datasets is an asset, but is not required. The experience with the Linux or Unix operating systems would be helpful.

Job Summary:
Work Description for Water Co-op Student

Environment and Climate Change Canada's (ECCC) Water Policy and Coordination Team is inviting a bright and enthusiastic university student (undergraduate or graduate level) to join our team to have the exciting opportunity to work toward addressing the Government of Canada's freshwater priorities. 


We provide a hands-on opportunity to participate in public policy making and strategic policy development in a supportive working environment. You will have a meaningful opportunity to put into practice what you have learned through your studies, while also developing the skills you will need for a successful career. This includes strengthening your communication, research and analytical skills. 


The team is currently playing a leadership role on federal freshwater policy development, and leads/supports intradepartmental, interdepartmental, and intergovernmental initiatives on fresh water, such as through the Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment and the Federal Freshwater Committee. In addition, the team is involved in international initiatives and requests, such as for the OECD and the United Nations. 


Description de travail pour un(e) étudiant(e) - Stage sur l'eau douce

L'équipe de la politique et de la coordination de l'eau à Environnement et Changement climatique Canada (ECCC) invite un étudiant universitaire brillant et enthousiaste (premier cycle ou cycles supérieurs) à se joindre à l'équipe pour avoir l'occasion unique de travailler sur les priorités fédérales en matière d'eau douce. 


Ce stage est une occasion de participer à l'élaboration de politiques publiques et stratégiques dans un environnement de travail positif. Vous aurez une occasion significative de mettre en pratique ce que vous avez appris durant vos études, tout en développant les compétences dont vous aurez besoin tout au long de votre carrière. Cela comprendra le renforcement de vos capacités de communication et de recherche. 


L'équipe joue actuellement un rôle de premier plan dans le développement de politiques de l'eau douce et supporte différentes initiatives intraministérielles, interministérielles et intergouvernementales sur l'eau douce, notamment via le Conseil canadien des ministres de l'environnement et le Comité fédéral de l'eau douce. L'équipe est également impliquée dans des demandes internationales sur l'eau à travers des forums multilatéraux comme les Nations Unies et l'OCDE.
Job Responsibilities:

conducting research and analysis on freshwater issues to inform government decision making;
supporting intra and interdepartmental committees;
supporting engagement activities; and
preparing briefings and advice to senior management (e.g., briefing notes, scenario notes, presentations).

Titre du poste : Analyste des politiques

Effectuer des recherches et des analyses sur des enjeux liés à l'eau douce, afin de soutenir les prises de décisions gouvernementales;
Supporter des groupes de travail intra- et interministérielles;
Supporter des activités de consultation; et
Préparer des notes d'information et formuler des recommandations à l'intention de la haute direction (p. ex., présentations, notes de scénario).
